A staggeringly fun surprise. There's no feeling like desperately dodge rolling, on critical health, as you fire the final rocket volley to kill a Carrier as the missile that should have finished you goes straight into the dying carrier. Or getting an attack approach on a enemy air squadron juuuuuust right to give you time to dump homing missiles at the ace's wingmen's exhausts and splash them before they can turn, before chasing the Ace down with cannons and sending him down in flames after he leads you on a just-above-ground tail chase.

Yes, it's a "rogue-lite", not usually a phrase I like at all, but here it works. Yeah, you start from scratch in terms of equipment and aircraft *levels*, but you unlock new weapons and airframes that you keep. It's a system that has a punishment for dying in the upgrade potentials, but that's never harsh enough to sting too hard. You just either shake up your bird and loadout, or go in again with the same, knowing more about the fantastically crafted little murder machine you're working with (or, not so little, if you go down the bomber line!).

And frankly, for the fun I've had so far, and still am, £15 is a damn good price. I've pissed away well over £40 on AAA games that turn out to be wet farts before, and this has all the feels of being a game that goes the distance at under half that. 

So, yeah, BUY THIS. It will reward you when you put the hard work in, make you swear when you forget you have the boost equipped and not flares and slam into the ground at what feels like 2000kph, and cheer when you overcome what annihilated your rookie arse five goes ago.

Another day, another game gets the roguelike treatment. This time it's a retro styled Ace Combat affair. Is it a Kenny Loggins success or just a bit bobbins?

How time flies. I can’t believe it's been 3 years since I initially backed the alpha of Sky Rogue on itch.io. I’d completely forgot about the title up until I received an update informing me that the game was finally out of early access and that the 1.0 point release was on Steam’s digital store

I was originally drawn to the game because I’m a sucker for simple filled polygons. This love of primitive shapes goes back to Starglider 2 on the Atari ST. A groundbreaking title, which was in its day, the pinnacle of 3D graphics. Time marches on and so does technology. What was once considered cutting edge is now just a twee retro aesthetic. I have no problem with that and activity seek out anything that employs this classic look.

I love a good dog fight, whether it's a Tie fighter, Sopwith Camel or a Eurofighter. There’s nothing quite like a high-speed joust between your foe in the open sky or vacuum of space. Getting on your opponents six and nailing them with whatever armaments your craft is equipped with is deeply satisfying. A personal favourite of mine is the lock on missile sound. It's a great audible cue that your enemies days are numbered. Flying through the debris of their shattered craft adds to the intoxicating gameplay mix.

The campaign mode is the meat of the game. This is where the rogue part of the game's title comes from. Set over 12 days, you are tasked with completing one mission per day. These are randomly generated. A sortie can include taking out out airborne targets such as lone AWACS planes, bomber squadrons or drones. Land based objective include sam sites, factories and command centres. There’s also the addition of naval encounters which can comprise of freighters and cruisers. As the campaign progressed the missions ramps up in difficulty. The opening couple of days are a cakewalk, taking out lone undefended Awacs is a turkey shoot. By day 4 it's a whole different ballgame. Blitzing a well-defended command centre surrounded by SAM sites is a tricky proposition, early warning radar scrambles drone and veteran units to fill the skies with a hornet's nest of feisty foes.

As you complete missions you receive Tech points(XP) and cash. The cash can be used to upgrade your arsenal items during missions. When you inevitably die, you get to spend your tech points based on your performance. If you level up, you'll get to pick a weapon/item/plane. Sometimes if you have done particularly well you get two choices. Then you start the whole shebang again, only now you have a bigger and more robust arsenal to tailor your mission load-outs.

The real star of the show is the ordinance that you can equip your aeros with. You start out with a rather humdrum arsenal but death by death you acquire some very nice kit. There’s all manner of guns, missiles and even drones to add to your loadout. I particularly like the long range AA missiles like the AAM-LR Longbow and AAM-MR Javelin. These long reach weapons allow your slower fighter-bombers to rule the sky from afar, way before any more agile foes can get in range and cause you harm. These are pure hog heaven and inject a sense of technical superiority as you press a button unleashing certain death upon your unwitting target. There’s an innate beauty watching a longbow missile arc across the azure sky, leaving a wispy vapour trail before blowing your enemy back into the dark ages.

In addition to the campaign, there are two more modes. Endless; this is the same as the main missions but without any end bosses and obviously goes on Infinitum. Free flight is the opening level devoid of any foes, allowing you to practise flying manoeuvres and try out different control schemes.

The soundtrack that accompanies all this air carnage is an amalgam of 16-bit cracktro styled tracks along with bombastic Advance Wars flavoured menu(GBA) tunage. They align beautifully with the prevailing retro aesthetic. Lots of pitch bending top lines, crest atop of pulsating FM bass lines and crunchy drum beats. Spot Fx for lock ons are on point and deliver a great audible 8bit beep feedback. Every weapon select is accompanied by suitable bleeps and bloops.

Graphics are pure Atari ST / Amiga era nostalgia. If you have ever played Carrier Command or Starglider then these will evoke days of yore. Clean immaculate low poly models zip through the skies in a vibrant retina burning basic colour world. Sonic blue is abound both in the liveries of the areos and the surrounding vista. Explosions are Heinz ketchup red and Coleman's mustard yellow. There’s no gritty COD browns or muted colours employed here. Everything has been painted with the primary palette of a Saturday morning cartoon. Bliss.

Sky rogue has come along way since its early alpha. I’m happy to report that all the issues I had with the control schemes have been ironed out. Gamepad support is tight and responsive. Using the Unity plugin rewire gives the player all the custom options to tweak the controls and button bindings for every function. There are more QOL features in the options menu. You have the choice of playing in arcade mode which doesn’t flip the entire screen when you pull off a barrel roll. Only the model spins. I call this feature the anti chunder/puke mode, for folks who suffer from motion sickness. Another option stops missiles from firing until you have a good lock on your targets. All these features are welcome and aid to a cool gameplay experience.

Sky rogue is a classic arcade shooter loving wrapped in a retro low poly aesthetic, folks who desire a quick dogfight with out all the usual time-consuming flight simulation baggage will find a lot of enjoyment from this tightly coded package. So play out your Iceman fantasies and jump into the danger zone!

I have been playing this game since it first went into early access and now that it has been released I can say that it's not that good. I was hoping that the issues I was having would get fixed up but now that it's been released I am giving up on that ever happening.

	The game isn't terrible by any stretch of the imagination, I wouldn't have played 45hrs of it if it was. Rather it has some fundamental design features which mean its just not that fun. This game is a great example of a sound game (a few bugs here and there but nothing game breaking) that falls flat because design choices which encourage unfun play.

My problems with the game fall broadly into 2 camps: The physics and the content(planes, weapons, enemies, etc.)
1. Physics:
	The problem here is that this game advertises itself as "a fwooshy rogue-lite action flight simulator". However the planes handle like thrust-vectoring, V8 powered biplanes in low gravity. Low top-speed, Low max altitude, low manuverablility at speed but insane low speed manoeuvring, insane power to weight ratio and insanely low stall speed.
	All but the heaviest planes can accelerate vertically, go from min speed to max speed in seconds, pull out of a stall with no problem, and pull a turn on a dime. It is my suspicion that there is almost no effect from air speed on pitch, yaw and roll rates (if anything it slows them down), this means that a plane can pull incredibly tight turns at very low speeds, but at top speeds (which aren’t very high), you end up controlling a freight train.
	All this results in a flight sim that doesn't feel "fwooshy" at all. I want to avoid bringing real planes into this as this isn't mean to be realistic and I am fine with that. However I feel that it should be mentioned that real planes manoeuvre (mostly) with flaps which have an effect proportional to air speed, higher speeds should me the planes roll faster however in game they roll like an A380 (even the fighters). I feel like, for this game to deliver on "fwooshy", you want planes that are fast, manoeuvrable but only at higher speeds and which can't decelerate to stall speed in no time at all. Under these circumstances, flying would be a joy, but that is not what you get in this game. In the end all dogfighting results in you spinning on the spot at minimum speed to line up a shot one the enemy (thing banshee duels in halo 1), which really isn’t fun.
	In all fairness there are a few planes which are faster and more manoverable and so almost approach "fwooshy" when flown in a certain way but that just brings me to the other set of issues.

TLDR: The flight physics are bad and the planes feel weird and slow, not "fwooshy". Also the dogfighting sucks, in an air combat game.


2. The content:
	This game has 9 planes of various roles, a bunch of weapons ranging from semi-active guided terminal homing long ranged air-to-air missiles, to cluster bombs, to rockets, to Gatling guns which play in a variety of different and interesting ways and which are good in a variety of situations against various targets. You use this to take on a range of targets such as enemy fighters, carriers, buildings, bombers, and ships. All on randomly generated islands which consist of 3 different biomes, each with its own topography.
	Sounds good right? Lots of variety to keep things interesting. Well, not really.
In this game, you aim is to take out the objective on a bunch of islands which consist of buildings, groups of planes flying on pre-set paths and the odd boat. They tell you what the objective is before you start the island however once you have launched you can't change your plane.
	Now, to get through the game you need to upgrade your weapons and plane, this takes money. This requires you to destroy buildings, especially on the early levels when there aren’t too many threats. However, buildings have high health so you need a high damage weapon to take them out in a decent timeframe, but the more powerful weapons are heavier and so can't be carried by the lighter, faster, "fwooshy"er planes. You could chip away with smaller weapons if you are patient but the carrier and aerodrome will be launching planes as you attack them so you really want to finish them quickly. So this encourages you to use heavier planes (bombers and heavy multi-role) which are slower and less fun to fly. However you cant change planes mid mission so you also need to dogfight in said plane, this means you need aa weapons and some manuverablility. This encourages you to use lighter planes (fighters, interceptors and multi-role) which have the avionics to equip good aa missiles.
	All this leaves you in the position of having to use a heavy, multi-role plane to carry bombs and missiles. There is only really one plane that fits the bill. So even though there are 9 planes in the game I found myself only ever using 3 of them tops, and mostly using one.

TLDR: The design choice around the content in the game mean that most of the options at your disposal are sub-optimal. You are forced to create an all round loadout to take out buildings and fighters and only a few things fit the bill. So, there is actually a lot less variety in this game than you think.

This all results in a game that is just not worth your time/money. This game could be great, and I had sky high hopes for it, online multiplayer, maybe a 5v5 pvp where you are trying to take out your opponents carrier, a better flight model with faster planes and larger maps, weapons to fill the gaps in the current arsenal to create more interesting choices, the ability to switch planes mid mission to allow for specialisation, better enemy ai, more interesting mechanics around bombing. 与PC平台上的另一款款知名现代空战游戏（H.A.W.X）相比，本作的内容显得单薄了不少：任务目标较为单一，只有摧毁空中目标和摧毁地面目标两种；至于护航，防御，支援任务？不存在的。地图咋一看有随机性，实则大同小异。前期和后期的关卡的区别也只体现在敌人的强度和数量上。

菜单里勾选Arcade Controls更容易上手，但默认的操纵方式更有乐趣，也能做出更灵活的机动（注意这两种方式的Y轴控制相反）。

战机选择
由于击落战斗机得到的收益很少，资金来源基本依赖于摧毁地面设施。本作中轻型战机由于载荷和电子设备捉急而缺乏火力，地位较为尴尬。个人偏好Ultimate multirole fighter：性能全面，只有速度慢一个缺点，而且可以靠带推进器弥补。

适合打击所有目标的万金油配置，总伤害不俗，装弹快。由于一次发射两颗，实际伤害是面板伤害x2。前期适合优先强化。缺点是射程短只能近距离格斗，飞行速度慢，后期高速狗斗中略无力。然而鉴于其威力和通用性作用仍不可小觑，毕竟有时扔一通炸弹或制导炸弹炸不掉一个防空炮还不如直接来两发导弹。

AA-IRMR眼镜蛇导弹
飞行速度更快，伤害更高，射程更远。由于锁定范围一般，开火间隔大，加上只能从后方攻击，伤害和射程的优势并不容易体现出来。再加上要占用更多的电子系统，个人认为不如它的小弟AA-IR好用。不过在需要大量对空火力的时候不妨带上。

与前两者相比，锁定方式不再依赖尾焰追踪，伤害足以秒杀大部分敌机。虽然锁定范围小，锁定时间长，但在长射程面前这些不算什么问题。不管从正面还是后面打击敌机都有不错的命中率。对战机的机动能力要求低，使用简单。

前期很好用，可以一次击落几架无人机。后期显得有些尴尬，火力分散以后往往一架飞机也打不下来，加上有时会去追踪一些不想打的目标比如母舰发动机，防空炮等。

没啥好说的，对固定目标利器，甚至可以用来炸任务里的大飞机[spoiler]（很容易炸死自己）[/spoiler]。

GB-1精确制导炸弹

[h1][b]Sky Rogue[/b][/h1]

When you're dying from Ace Combat 7 News Drought™ and you see a game like Sky Rogue during the Steam summer sale (perhaps assisted somewhat by Ace Combat Fan's livestream), there's only one thing left to do. This marks my second (and perhaps last) purchase during the 2017 summer sale, and I must say it was a good decision, indeed, especially for an Early Access title.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Sky Rogue hardly stands up to recent Ace Combat titles (or similar) in terms of detail, but this game isn't trying to - it has a charming, simple, yet consistent art-style that is easy on the eyes, and it contains plenty of varied, unique designs for aircraft to go along with that style. The heads-up display is easily readable, and the UI is also simple and easy to use. Unlike some titles, I won't be able to ramble on here about graphics artifacts or the rendering of bees flying between the blades of grass, but this game nonetheless more than 'does the job' visually.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
Sky Rogue comes with an array of unique retro-style sounds for its weapons, aircraft, and UI, and all more than do the job - weapons, in particular, sound distinct from one another and memorable, especially the long-range air-to-air missiles. The soundtrack is quite fine, though it can become slightly repetitive as each particular 'zone' in the single-player mode uses one track at the time of this review. While you might opt to turn down the in-game music and start playing [url=https://youtu.be/9G1ob5jnuSo]Comona[/url] instead, the game's own music is quite alright by my book.

[h1]Performance[/h1]
While I have yet to test it on a laptop, it performs perfectly on my desktop, as one would hope. I have also yet to encounter any bugs that impede progress in any way, leaving me quite impressed with this Early Access title. In fact, the only bug I have encountered was when a ship decided to sail through the land - hardly game-breaking, but... [i]interesting[/i] to say the least. Based on other reviews, however, I have no reason to doubt the performance on less-than-stellar machines.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
As a fan of the classic Ace Combat formula, I found all that (and a little more) here in Sky Rogue. The basic premise is simple: Choose an aircraft (or, as the game calls them, an aero), pick out up to four weapons and a piece of specialized equipment to load on-board, then launch off the deck of your floating carrier-blimp to complete your objectives. Weapons come in a variety of shapes, sizes, and for different purposes; various types of guns, air-to-air infrared, radar-guided, and dumb-fire missiles and rockets, plus bombs, and some unique pieces of kit to replace the ordinary flares ensures the game not only has plenty of replayability, but also supports various flying styles to complete your mission. My only real complaint in regard to the gameplay overall would have to be the lack of proper dogfight AI as of the time of this review. Enemy aeros will happily chase after you and fire off a missile or two, but will then veer off in another direction before coming around again - I haven't been in any tight turning fights yet, something I hope to see in later versions of Sky Rogue.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=961806394

[h1]Singleplayer[/h1]
Most of the time you'll spend in Sky Rogue will be in singleplayer, either in the dynamic campaign, endless mode, or custom scenarios. The campaign starts off simple and ramps up in difficulty the more missions you complete, and as the name suggests, your progress will be reset if you crash. Fear not, however, as any unlocked weapons and aeros will stay; only upgrades and campaign progress are lost - though this is for the best, as the upgrades do significantly empower your aero and its weapons, and would make the early stages a bit too easy. I have to say, though, that there is plenty of replayability in the singleplayer alone, and it is, no doubt, enough of a draw to bring in most fans of arcade air combat.

[h1]Multiplayer[/h1]
As of the time of this review, multiplayer comes in the form of a local split-screen cooperative campaign mode, with two 'aeronauts' for the price of one Sky Rogue. It's just as fun as single-player (if not more so thanks to the addition of a comrade to help you down your foes), though I do hope to see proper online multiplayer in the future, as well as perhaps an adversarial dogfighting mode in addition to cooperative play.

[h1]Community Content[/h1]
Sky Rogue does come with Steam Workshop integration, and much to my adoration the first mod to appear on the Workshop was the ADFX-01 Morgan:  [url=https://youtu.be/80XAJKqRU9k][b]<<[/b] Here comes the snow! [b]>>[/b][/url]  A host of other mods, including new aeros and missions, have already been released, though one might want to keep in mind the less consistent visual style with community-created aeros. Still, having reached this point, I can say Sky Rogue has checked all the boxes I hoped it would.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
For any would-be Aces in search of a respite from that insatiable excitement for Ace Combat 7, Sky Rogue may prove to be just the game for you. Indeed, I can see myself still playing it long after Project Aces' newest title finally releases, as it is just that fun and dynamic - and, of course, just different enough - compared to replaying older Ace Combat titles again and again to earn a spot on my favorites list. Forkbeard, you've done something not many others could, and I commend you for it, and hope to see it grow further as time goes by.

[b]I recommend Sky Rogue.[/b]

No matter how many times I play the same three missions over and over again, trying to better my score while staying alive (because if you die, you have to start from the beginning) never gets boring, thanks to the procedurally generated landscapes and enemy placements. I can never expect to find the same set of factories, satelites, command towers and surface defense guns to be in the exact same place all the time, and that keeps things fresh. Not to mention, the missions are always straightforward as well. No special requirements or objectives, and no limitations of fighters or weapons. Pick a fighter, arm it, and go take out the mission targets. That's it! Nothing fancy! Just get out there and take 'em down!
One thing I did not expect is that after I destroy the last mission target and complete the mission, the mission doesn't necessarily have to be "over". If I want to, I can still take down the swarms of drones and fighters that have been pestering me throughout my struggle to take down the mission targets, or clear the rest of the island of its ground and sea targets.

GAMEPLAY

I am using the Thrustmaster T.Flight HOTAS X Stick and it works out perfectly well. Although there are no presettings for using a Joystick, the setup is pretty quick and easy. You can personalize all buttons very well and thus, I strongly recommend using a joystick or better a HOTAS for the game, which I believe is crucial for the fun factor of the game.

Gameplay feels GREAT. You can literally feel all the properties of the different plane types you are flying and the effects of how you fly. The principle is very easy to learn and becomes more and more challenging, as you fly different random mission from your base (A flying Aircraft carrier). You will have to either destroy enemy bases on the ground in awesome bombing runs or battle bogeys and aces in challenging dogfights with your steadily growing arsenal of all different sorts of weapons. Once you successfully complete a mission and return to your base, a new mission will wait for you. With every mission you complete, your enemies will get stronger and harder to ward off, but if you die once, you will be back at the beginning and have to start all over again. All upgrades you afforded will also be lost. 
For each kill, you will earn Tech points (which are not going to be reset) and proceed in your Tech Level, wich will unlock new planes and weapons. The planes not only differ as to how they look like, but there is also a great deal changed about their handling, speed and their payload (How much weaponry they can carry)

The gameplay itself is pretty easy to master but still quite challenging. Your weapon pool's arsenal consists of guide Air to Air missiles and Air to Ground missiles which will have to be locked on to an enemy before firing them off, bombs, unguided missiles and machine guns/Flaks. You always have to carefully chose, which weapons to take with you in which plane, as they have limited payloads and only four slots.
You also have the ability to equip a fifth slot either with flares (You can dump flares to ward off enemy missiles), drone wingmans which can be launched to help you or a speed booster. 
There are different skins you can fit to your planes for every personal style. All of them look good.

GRAPHICS

There isn't much to say about Graphics. Sky Rogue's Graphics are not at all impressive, but they have a very nice low-polygon style. Though there are many low-polygon games, Sky Rogue maintains a very personal style, making the game charming and unique. Thus, the performance is great, even on low-end PCs like mine (Intel Core 0.03 at 1Hz), even at highest graphic settings. 

MODDING

Modding is one of the most important features of this game. Even if you might get tired of the main game after a few hours of playing it, there will be always an extremely wide range of mods which feature awesome fictional and real-world airplanes to get a new shot of enthusiasm into your veins and also custom missions. Mods are also verz easz to create and if you are looking for a particulat plane and can't find it, there are plenty of guides to help you create your personal mod.
*HOWEVER* Don't tap into the trap of downloading OP planes like I did before, as this will destroy the fun factor completely. It should always be challenging!

REVIEW

This game is AWESOME and well worth the 10 quit. You will get that top gun feeling, shooting down endlessly many bogeys and bombing infinitely many buildings, Dodging enemy missiles with daring barrel roll maneuvers and dumping flares at them. This game is what you are going to be in the skies. an ACE!

If you like Arcade Flight 'Sim' - BUY NOW!

This game is a light alternative to intense simulators for those who just want to get airborne, blow stuff up, but also want challenging opposition instead of enemies that couldn't hit a barn.

[u] Fox two! [/u]

With the lack of real triple-A flight simulators coming out lately, Sky Rogue attempts to take the reigns and create an arcade-like aircraft game. But does it succeed?

[u] Gameplay [/u]

I'll be happy to report that the gameplay is the highlight of Sky Rogue. Choosing from a variety of planes which you unlock, as well as a loadout from a colorful and fun weapon pool, you take to the skies in a brillant fashion. Launched from your mothership, you complete randomly assigned missions. This can range from average bombings to taking on entire battleships. 

Movement feels fluid, and you can feel the agility and weight of your planes with every sick turn or twist. For evasion, you have a simple, but effective dodge roll which usually throws missiles off. Barring that, you can equip flares for a big middle finger towards your missile slinging foes. Your weapons are large-scale and always ready to chew up the opposition. Explosives, lock-on missiles, machine guns, and much more are available as you steadily progress through the game. When you inevitably get shot down, you are sent back to mission 1, but not before unlocking some permanently acquired equipment with your hard earned "Tech" points. 

Note that this game works with your HOTUS setup, and (apparently) feels great!

[u] Graphics [/u]

The graphics of Sky Rogue aren't exactly impressive, but have a very low-polygon charm that is done intentionally. It looks great and doesn't seem to impede with performance too much. Certainly colorful as well, with bright explosions, gaudy color schemes, and a blue sky at your hull.

[u] Performance [/u]

Runs great, even on my potato of a PC. Supports DirectX9 and DirectX11. Solid 60 while playing on the highest graphics, and even runs at 50-60 while recording if I bump the graphics down to low.

[u] Longevity [/u]

Sky Rogue has a modding community that seems fairly talented and dedicated to making up some ridiculously cool or funny looking planes. Custom missions are also littered through the workshop, though I haven't personally tried any of them out. The developers are responsive and work at a moderate pace. They seem to have things sorted out, though they also seem behind schedule. Still, the game currently has a fairly good amount of content, well worth its 10 dollar price tag.

[u] Verdict [/u]

Now this is what I'd call a great flght-and-flight game. You'll feel like a real badass ace flying through the skies, shooting down enemy drones and bombing countless amounts of buildings, all while dodging the wall of missiles and flak that impede you fruitlessly. 

Well worth the 10 dollars, be sure to get it while it's hot!

那么对于这个游戏来说呢？

Sky Rogue选择了只做一个几乎在休闲类目里面已经无可挑剔了的飞行系统，和一个简洁但是也同样无可挑剔的明快画面。微型追踪弹，空对空导弹，对地炸弹，该有的都有，而且也有不同的视觉刺激。随着游戏流程的不断推进，你还能解锁新的飞机类型，装备。但是，听不到Roger!的空战游戏，真的只能被看作在花园中闲逛而非有分毫的罗曼蒂克氛围。而且游戏因为对地操作相当多，飞机本身就不常进入高速状态，空中缠斗也因为周围云都不动而让人感到不是很带感。相比另一款销量挺接近的却主打剧情音乐配音的空战游戏来说，Sky Rogue的游戏性基础是要踏实有趣的多的。但是玩起来如何就是见仁见智了。

На момент написания отчёта имеется: одиночная игра, 6 часов налёта, 29 тех. уровень и множество боевых вылетов на различных типах самолётов, большинство которых закончилось фатально. Сплит-скрин мультиплеер, пока что единственный многопользовательский режим, не тестировался.

Несмотря на минималистичный дизайн, картинка радует глаз - сочно и с "голливудом" ярких спецэффектов, но не в ущерб боевой эффективности.

Сама игра - собственно это ясно и из названия - "Небесный рогалик". В наличии у игрока: самолёт (с вооружением на выбор), свой летающий авианосец (для ремонта, смены вооружения или самолёта, или и того, и другого) и процедурно генерируемый остров со случайным заданием.
Схема проста, но множество нюансов заставляют играть снова и снова, наплевав на неудачи, и совершенствовать полётное мастерство. За каждую выполненную миссию и сбитого врага выдаются деньги, которые можно тратить на улучшение имеющегося вооружения в "Аэролаборатории", делая его более смертоносным, дальнобойным и скорострельным. Выполнил миссию - переходи в следующий "день" с новой миссией и новыми, более сильными противниками. 
"Жизнь" при этом всего одна - стоит врагу превратить твой агрегат крылатой смерти в кучу дымящихся обломков, наступает неизбежная расплата - "день" сбрасывается на первый и все проведённые апгрейды и накопленные деньги обнуляются. Но нет худа без добра - после каждой смерти все уничтоженные цели начисляются в "опыт" для нового тех. уровня. С каждым новым уровнем предлагается выбор одной технологии - это может быть как вооружение, так и вспомогательная система или новый самолёт. При этом тех. уровень при "смерти" не теряется.
У каждого самолёта имеется одинаковое число ячеек: четыре под оружие, одну - под вспомогательное оборудование (например, вспышки для отвода самонаводящихся ракет) и одну - под "шкурку". Для установки оружие требует различное число "загрузки" и "авионики" - двух показателей, различных для каждого самолёта помимо скорости, манёвренности и прочности.
Число комбинаций просто огромно - помимо множества видов (пулемёты, все виды ракет, бомбы), никто не запрещает ставить несколько одинаковых для увеличения боезапаса. При этом ограничения количества снарядов нет - боезапас восполняется со временем.

Единственное, с чем перемудрили - так это с управлением (и то, только для фанатов "Ace Combat"). В общем-то оно такое же, только развёрнуто на 180 градусов в обоих направлениях, и легко перенастраивается в случае необходимости. Также рекомендую сразу отключить автопереключение цели - прицел легко может перескочить с преследуемого ракетного дрона на какой-нибудь ангар, что иногда просто фатально (особенно где-то на третий "день").

[u] Заключение: [/u]

Во-первых и самых главных - уже на стадии альфы игра определённо удалась! Приятно играть, интересно комбинировать. 
Вылетов за время игры не было. В одной из миссий по уничтожению "АВАКСов" данный агрегат умудрился улететь далеко за пределы карты, пришлось догонять и наказывать.

Sky Rogue is a distillation of the combat flight sim genre, whittling it down to its action-packed essence. This is not a game about realism or technical complexity, nor about peaceful and lengthy flights. It bears far more resemblance to StarFox or classic Top Gun games than to DCS or Falcon BMS. You will be fighting enemies the minute you're off the deck, often in overwhelming numbers. Ammunition recharges, and planes can pull of maneuvers a MiG pilot could only dream of. But there is balance in Sky Rogue's simplicity. It packs in arcade-y style to make it fun to just pick up and play, but it retains just enough realism to make you feel like you're actually flying. The planes are more maneuverable than some real-life aircraft, but you do still have to think about stalling, gravity, and how your speed is affecting your turn rate. Ammunition regenerates, but weapons have limitations like radar cones. Everything, whether flying, shooting, or dodging enemy fire, has a nice visceral feel to it. 

Sky Rogue is the perfect pick-up-and-play combat flight sim. There's enough complexity of systems and skill required to give it longevity, but you won't need to watch a 4-hour tutorial just to be able to play the game. And you won't need to devote an hour to playing at a stretch. You can pick it up and play it for however long you want, be that 5 minutes or 5 hours.

This isn't Ace Combat, not even quite an Ace Combat 'lite', but it is as good an arcade stand-in as I've found.

Basically, you unlock new planes, weapons and items (flare alternatives, boosters, etc) by playing randomly generated levels each containing a random mission from a limited selection of types. As you play and kill stuff you get cash and experience and increase your 'tech level', unlocking new stuff as your tech level increases. If you are killed in a mission, you cash in your XP and money, select new items/weapons/planes to unlock and start again from level 1.

An interesting feature I enjoy is being able to choose the load-outs for every plane you have unlocked and being able to use any one of these planes during a mission, switching between them by landing on your carrier. This lets you play with tactics, choosing planes with large load capacity which can take a lot of punishment and using them as bombers, while choosing planes with good avionics and speed as fighters. Something to note, when you are killed, your loadouts are reset and some weapons are relocked, meaning you have to repurchase the weapons you want to use (if they are now locked) and resetup your loadouts.

Tl:dr - Fun little rogue-like with a decent amount of replayability for those who like quick drop-in games (20 minutes or so at a time). Unlockable content seems to slow down by level 25 and the missions, enemies and islands are failr samey. Combat feels fun and fairly fast-paced, weapons have a decent feel to them.

Enjoyable little arcade shooter, but needs work to give it staying power past an hour or two.

Currently, Sky Rogue is in alpha. This gets you: a single level, a small cluster of islands in the middle of the ocean. Not a lot, admittedly. The landmass in the middle of the ocean might be randomly generated between waves; I didn't pay enough attention to tell you if they were. At the start of play, you're given an objective or objectives ("HANGAR", "2 COMMAND", "3 AWACS" etc), and you customize your plane and weapon loadout to suit your needs. You start with a single plane with three basic weapons, but upon subsequent deaths you unlock more weapons and planes in what seems to be some hidden slot machine mechanic. 

You then launch from your skybound aircraft carrier, blow up designated targets, and then fly back to the carrier to end the "Day," the game's designation for waves.  The game ups you to the next day, with harder enemies and more objectives. You're given the chance to reconfigure your aircraft before the next mission. Fairly simple.

The game's strength lies in its tight control scheme. Controls are responsive; your sci-fi jet fighter, obedient. Those who have played Ace Combat will feel instant familiarity, though the traditional button to change targets in AC is, in Sky Rogue, the button to swap weapons. I suffered several rounds of accidentally cycling through my weapons before I had the good sense to change the key bindings on my 360 gamepad. Chasing down enemy fighters, dodging missiles, and swerving out of the way of enemy AWACS tumbling out of the sky is a treat, particularly for those of us longing for Namco to revive the AC franchise. 

There are some downsides that make Sky Rogue tough to recommend. For one, you're locked into a single, uninteresting map. After a few rounds, I was desperate for something—ANYTHING—different than green clumps surrounded by blue water. Second, the music. Rather, the song. There is a single tune that accompanies you in the air, a chiptune throwback to the SNES era. It's highly reminisicent of a Starfox tune, and while it starts out catchy it soon becomes irksomely repetitive. 

Last, and most important, is the unfortunate fact that most the mission objectives are a chore. If the game is feeling charitable, it might throw a couple AWACS planes your way. Chasing down the AWACS and their fighter escorts is fast and tense—one might forget they weren't playing Ace Combat for a minute. Sadly, the common objectives are fortified ground targets, buildings that take many, many passes with anti-ground ordinance to destroy. From Day 3 onwards, these ground objectives are surrounded by long-range SAM sites, making carpet bombing from above the ideal tactic. This is exceptionally boring, as it requires you to line up your shots with an insufferable slow targeting reticle that shrinks when your plane is not pitching or yawing, and then turn around and repeat the process multiple times. Worse, as you'll have brought an aircraft built around bombing and not air-to-air intercept for these, you'll be at the AI's mercy when it throws its higher level fighters at you.

The game is in Early Access, but there's the rub: as we've seen over and over the past couple years, there's no guarantee that an EA game will ever progress beyond its current alpha form.  After a couple hours of play, I was stuck with the feeling, "Is that all there is?" I tend to play Ace Combat on Ace difficulty, and it does not take long for me to reach the point where I can progress no further in Sky Rogue. I hit my inevitable death after passing by for my fourth bombing run of a target, get tossed back to the beginning, and it feels like something's missing. Variety, perhaps. Or maybe I'm missing the fun. There's a game in here somewhere that I very much enjoy and very much want to play more of, but it's locked behind uninteresting, ultimately futile bombing missions on an unintersting group of islands in the middle of an uinteresting sea. Ultimate, Sky Rogue strikes me as one of those games that comes inside another game as a distraction or Easter egg, not a retail product. 

Perhaps the game will expand, but perhaps not. This is Early Access, after all, where nothing is certain. I would not hedge my bets on the game making good on its implicit promise of scratching that itch we feel for a good arcade flight game, and cannot, therefore, in good conscience recommend this game. If you are absolutely desperate to feel the thrill of the Ace Combat games, wait for a sale. Yes, it's only $10, but you should still wait for a sale. 

I also hear that a PS2 emulator will play AC4 just fine, so there's that.

This early access game offers some of the best arcade dogfighting I've experienced, but I'm even more impressed by how remarkably well-balanced the missions are. Missions objectives generally consist of destroying static targets surrounded by defenses like AA guns and SAM sites. In early missions you can dodge or ignore defenses and take out targets directly, but it soon becomes necessary to remove layers of defense before you can attack targets without being blown apart by a hail of missiles. You can return to base to repair your plane or switch to a different plane or loadout, allowing you to specialize for the current phase of the mission, but spawners---carriers in the air and aerodromes on the ground---pose an interesting complication, since you need to balance your capability to destroy the aircraft they're launching and the spawner itself.

There are multiple effective strategies. For dispatching enemy aircraft you can outfit a maneuverable craft with fast, short-range missiles and engage in topsy-turvy dogfights, but with too many foes in the mix you'll inevitably take some hits, and maneuverable planes aren't so durable. Or you can put long-range missiles in a fast interceptor, outrun your enemies, and be the ultimate jouster, but this isn't as expedient as close-in dogfirghting and you might not be able to destroy enemies as fast as a spawner produces them. Or can try to make an all-around fighter that's decent at all three of dogfighting, ranged anti-air, and bombing, and hope you're still nimble enough to win dogfights. Yes, you can switch planes mid-mission, but if you're being pursued by a faster enemy you might not survive the trip back to base. Ground targets can also be taken out multiple ways: bombed from altitude, dive-bombed, or strafed with rockets, guns, and cannons.

It only takes a few hours to unlock almost all the planes and items, giving you a wide variety of loadouts and strategies to experiment with, and 14 hours in I'm still uncovering new strategies for getting to later missions. Excellent work, Fractal Phase.

This game is excellent. Lately, I've found myself with an overwhelming desire to blow enemy aircraft out of the gorgeous blue sky at all hours of the day. It's just as easy to get short, bite-sized play sessions out of this game as it is to sit around for an hour trying to progress past day 4. Make no mistake: this game can get difficult. -Replayability. Set in a world where the average pilot life expectancy is less than two days, the focus on flight combat and procedurally generated maps keeps the gameplay fresh. You'll play those first few days over and over, but you'll find it just as fun as the AI finds you repulsive and in need of death.

Not so much:
-Music. There is one track that plays during flight. That's it. It's catchy, but it's just the one.

-Stats. This game should track pilot statistics. After referencing average pilot life expectancy earlier, I want this concept in the game.

Sky Rogue is currently in alpha, so don't expect a fully polished experience. That said, this game is worth your money and your time right now. So buy it already.

I love this game, it was well worth the money I paid even in its Early Access state.

The game is pretty simple and straightforward:
- Pick one of the planes you've unlocked
- Customize your loadout with up to 4 weapon systems, accounting for different weapon types, stats, and costs
- Don't forget to choose one of the liveries, there's a good selection and they're all immediately available
- Fly around and blow stuff up.

The mission objectives are deceptively simple. Blow up 2 labs? Easy Peasy; until you realize that each is surrounded by SAM and AA turrets. You make a few passes, but then you see that the Alert Level has gone up. Fighters are launching from nearby hangars, carriers, and/or aerodromes. This mission just became much more complicated.

You get one life, one shot at each "day". Early in a "day" you'll have full health and a couple mission targets; but as you shift your attention to fighters, the facilities that launch them, and weather the AA defenses the mission gets much more difficult. You really only need to blow up your target, but kills/destruction grant extra points and can reduce incoming fire during strafing runs. You'll have to decide between getting a mission done quickly at high risk, or try to endure long enough to take out all the defenses.

When you inevitably die, you get XP based on your performance. If you level up, you'll get to pick a weapon/item/plane from a small random selection. Then you're thrown into a new Day 1 with a new mission. Every Day/Mission is randomly generated, going from 'moderate' on Day 1 to 'impossibly hard' a few days later.

In my first draft of this review, I said you could "skip" a day. I was incorrect. If you land on a friendly pad or return to your carrier BEFORE destroying your Mission Target, you can change your loadout and re-launch with full health. Once your target has been destroyed, landing on any pad will end the mission.

I'm already happy with my purchase, I would definitely recommend this game to fans of other arcade-style flight games like Strike Vector, HAWX, Ace Combat Assault Horizon, or Crimson Skies.
